author: sky.cactus
content: I don't like premium for the same reason as I don't like fee.  Both terms imply a "total", not a "per unit" cost.

author: sky.cactus
content: IMO, price very clearly indicates "per unit" cost in common English usage.

author: sky.cactus
content: "Fee" and "Premium" both imply some total or aggregate cost.

author: sky.cactus
content:
Another option is to just be a bit more verbose:
```
miner premium per gas
miner fee per gas
miner reward per gas
inclusion incentive per gas
```

author: sky.cactus
content: There is a risk that people start dropping the "per gas" suffix in casual writing, and eventually that turns into jargon and it is dropped even in more formal writing, and we are back to the problem of new users reading stuff and not understanding by default.

author: .vbuterin
content: I think realistically people already mentally perceive "gwei" as being per-gas

author: .vbuterin
content: "price" can work; it definitely has an established precedent of being per-gas in ethereum

author: sky.cactus
content: To Ethereum experts/regulars who already speak the jargon yes.  I would like it if things were understandable to people who are not already experts and don't already know the jargon though.

author: sky.cactus
content: The goal, IMO, should be to minimize jargon as much as possible and instead prefer to lean on connotative meanings of words as understood by the general population.

author: sky.cactus
content: By calling it "price", we are leaning on everyone's regular-world experience with that word which *often* is associated with a per-unit cost.

author: .vbuterin
content: The reason why jargon can sometimes be good for understandability is that any word that already has meanings to the general population also often has connotative meanings that we would prefer to avoid and that would confuse people

author: .vbuterin
content: Even the word "coin" in bitcoin is one example of this: it creates the impression that you can't have fractional units of it

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, I agree.  Do you think that "price" comes with such connotation here?

author: .vbuterin
content: I would say price is generic enough that it's fine

author: .vbuterin
content: "rate" is more explicitly a ratio, but it's ambiguous between "quantity provided per unit time" and "money paid per unit quantity"

author: sky.cactus
content:
```
rate cap
base rate
miner rate
```

author: .vbuterin
content: Also we have a limited attention budget with which to retrain our existing community, so keeping the price terminology seems ideal

author: .vbuterin
content: I'd still say price better than rate there; "base rate" reminds me of the concept of base rates from statistic

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm less worried about mathematicians misunderstanding the system than Joe Six Pack.

author: .vbuterin
content: Another option is `fee_level`

author: .vbuterin
content: base_fee_level, miner_incentive_fee_level, maximum_fee_level

author: sky.cactus
content: "fee_level" makes me pause and wonder what it means (which can be good or bad).

author: .vbuterin
content: I'm inclined to say good; you should definitely not walk past EIP 1559 and think you understand it without having paused ðŸ˜†

author: sky.cactus
content: Heh, true.  I'm more worried about mom and pop users in the distant future though than EIP-1559 readers.

author: sky.cactus
content: And I suspect whatever terminology we use in 1559 is what will eventually be exposed to mom and pop in the future.

author: .vbuterin
content: I actually think that the fact that "gwei" is only ever used as a unit for transaction fees saves us a lot. I think most people don't mentally think of "gwei" as a quantity of ether, they think of gwei as some spooky thing that ends up being proportional to the amount of ETH they spend in a weird way

author: sky.cactus
content: (since that historically has been what has happened, much to my frustration)
